Executive Summary



-Introduction to Risk Management Program-



A Risk Management Program (RMP) has been developed for the House of Raeford facility in Arcadia, Louisiana. The Risk Management Plan for the House of Raeford Arcadia facility has been prepared for the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia in the facility's refrigeration system. Each part of the RMP is submitted to the Environmental Protection Agency, meeting or exceeding the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68. 



The submission is due to the need to fulfill the requirements mandated by the EPA for a new submission or an update to occur every 5 years. The RMP was resubmitted in accordance with the 5-year update requirement. The RMP resubmission was completed on January 11, 2021. Following EPA Guidance provided during an audit, House of Raeford removed a second unnecessary Worst-Case Scenario and updated inaccurate population estimates for offsite impacts. Additionally, emergency contact information has been updated.



-Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response or Emergency Action Policies-



The House of Raeford Arcadia facility recognizes management's responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property. The safety and health of all personnel are very important. The controls of accidents have been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the House of Raeford Arcadia facility.



To accomplish the company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established an Emergency Action Plan. The objectives of the Emergency Action Plan are: to maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering and the economic burden resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.



One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response or action prog

rams which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and EPA's Risk Management Program regulation. Jeff White, the Refrigeration Supervisor/PSM Coordinator, is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.



The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response or emergency action programs is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses, environmental impact and avoid physical property damage.



The accidental release prevention and emergency response or emergency action programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and are improved, as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.



-Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled -



The House of Raeford Arcadia facility includes one (1) ammonia refrigeration process in two (2) systems with cooling and freezing capabilities. House of Raeford processes and freezes poultry products for distribution. 



The EPA defines a process as any activity involving a regulated substance including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or on-site movement of such substances, or combination of these activities. For the purposes of this definition, any group of vessels that are interconnected, or separate vessels that are located such that a regulated substance could be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process. 



The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7664-41-7) contained in the process exceeds 10,000 pounds. The maximum quantity of ammonia held during the calendar year in the process is 35,000 lbs. of ammonia. Since an ammonia release from

the systems could pose a risk of offsite public and/or environmental impact and the system regulated, the systems are subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RM program.



The Prevention Program: 



The Accidental Release Prevention Program focuses on efforts at the House of Raeford Arcadia facility to contain the refrigerant inside the systems. The goal is to reduce the risk of injury and promote safer practices at the House of Raeford Arcadia facility. The following items are included in the Prevention Program in relation to requirements for Program Level 3.



1.    Employee Participation (EP)

2.    Process Safety Information (PSI)

3.    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

4.    Operating Procedures (OP)

5.    Training (TR)

6.    Contractors (C)

7.    Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

8.    Mechanical Integrity (MI)

9.    Hot Work Permit (HW)

10.    Management of Change (MOC)

11.    Incident Investigation (II)

12.    Emergency Planning and Response Program (EP&R)

13.    Compliance Audits (CA)

14.    Trade Secrets (TS) 



Each of these elements play a role in identifying, evaluating, controlling, and preventing potential hazards associated with the ammonia system. Each element is reviewed and updated with frequencies in accordance with regulations on the EPA and OSHA standards.



-Five-Year Accident History-



No reportable accidents have occurred at the House of Raeford Arcadia facility in the last 5 years. A sample accident report can be found in the Process Safety Management Files. 



-Emergency Response Program-



The House of Raeford Arcadia facility has designated roles and procedures for small leak response as well as a qualified HAZMAT team for large leak response. For larger incidents, House of Raeford Arcadia is included in the community's emergency response plan.



The Emergency Action Plan is kept with the Process Safety Management Files. 



-Planned Changes to Improve Safety-



Based upon ColonialWebb Contractor recommendations, and goals for continued improvement,

the facility has begun the following plans to improve safety. These items will be assigned responsible parties, tracked and implemented, or closed out with proper justification, to ensure the facility's ammonia refrigeration systems continue to operate safely.

-    Operator refresher training

-    Updated SOP Training Procedures

-    Improved daily round inspections

-    Continued development of PSM Software Implementation (APSM)
